slides.title: Hosted Runners
slides.content:
# Hosted (Cloud) Runners â˜ï¸

Platform-provided runners for quick setup.

## GitHub Actions Runners

```yaml
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest  # Linux
    # runs-on: macos-latest  # macOS
    # runs-on: windows-latest  # Windows
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - run: echo "Hello from hosted runner!"
```

## Available Environments

| Platform | Linux | macOS | Windows |
|----------|-------|-------|--------|
| GitHub | âœ… ubuntu-* | âœ… macos-* | âœ… windows-* |
| GitLab | âœ… Linux | âœ… macOS | âœ… Windows |
| Bitbucket | âœ… Linux | âŒ | âŒ |

## Pre-installed Software

Hosted runners come with:
- Programming languages (Node, Python, Java, etc.)
- Build tools (npm, pip, Maven, etc.)
- Container tools (Docker, docker-compose)
- Cloud CLIs (AWS, Azure, GCP)
- Common utilities (git, curl, wget)

## Limitations

| Constraint | Typical Limit |
|------------|---------------|
| Build time | 6 hours |
| Disk space | 10-14 GB |
| Memory | 7-14 GB |
| Concurrency | Varies by plan |

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Check the runner images documentation for full software list!

slides.title: Self-Hosted Runners
slides.content:
# Self-Hosted Runners ğŸ–¥ï¸

Run CI jobs on your own infrastructure.

## Why Self-Host?

- ğŸ”’ **Security** - Keep code on-premise
- âš¡ **Performance** - Powerful custom hardware
- ğŸ’° **Cost** - Reduce cloud costs at scale
- ğŸ›ï¸ **Control** - Custom software and config
- ğŸŒ **Network** - Access internal resources

## GitHub Actions Self-Hosted

```bash
# Download and configure runner
mkdir actions-runner && cd actions-runner
curl -o runner.tar.gz -L https://github.com/actions/runner/releases/download/v2.x.x/actions-runner-linux-x64-2.x.x.tar.gz
tar xzf runner.tar.gz

# Configure
./config.sh --url https://github.com/org/repo --token YOUR_TOKEN

# Run as service
sudo ./svc.sh install
sudo ./svc.sh start
```

## Using Self-Hosted Runners

```yaml
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: self-hosted
    # Or with labels:
    # runs-on: [self-hosted, linux, gpu]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - run: ./build.sh
```

## Runner Labels

```yaml
runs-on: [self-hosted, linux, x64, gpu]
```

Labels match runners with specific capabilities.

> âš ï¸ **Security:** Self-hosted runners should only run trusted code!

slides.title: Environment Variables
slides.content:
# Variables in CI ğŸ”§

Configure builds with **environment variables**.

## Variable Types

### 1. Built-in Variables

```yaml
# GitHub Actions
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - run: |
          echo "Repository: $GITHUB_REPOSITORY"
          echo "Branch: $GITHUB_REF_NAME"
          echo "Commit: $GITHUB_SHA"
          echo "Actor: $GITHUB_ACTOR"
          echo "Run ID: $GITHUB_RUN_ID"
```

### 2. Custom Variables

```yaml
# Workflow-level
env:
  NODE_ENV: production
  API_URL: https://api.example.com

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    # Job-level
    env:
      DATABASE: postgres
    steps:
      - name: Use variables
        # Step-level
        env:
          STEP_VAR: value
        run: echo $NODE_ENV $DATABASE $STEP_VAR
```

## Variable Scope

| Scope | Visibility |
|-------|------------|
| **Workflow** | All jobs and steps |
| **Job** | All steps in job |
| **Step** | Single step only |

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Use lower scope for step-specific values!

slides.title: Secrets Management
slides.content:
# Secrets ğŸ”

Secure storage for **sensitive** configuration.

## Why Secrets?

```yaml
# âŒ NEVER do this!
env:
  API_KEY: "sk_live_abc123xyz"  # Exposed in repo!

# âœ… Use secrets instead
env:
  API_KEY: ${{ secrets.API_KEY }}  # Encrypted
```

## Adding Secrets

### GitHub
1. Settings â†’ Secrets and variables â†’ Actions
2. New repository secret
3. Name and value

### GitLab
1. Settings â†’ CI/CD â†’ Variables
2. Add variable
3. Check "Mask variable" and "Protect variable"

## Using Secrets

```yaml
jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Deploy
        env:
          AWS_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY }}
          AWS_SECRET_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_KEY }}
        run: ./deploy.sh
```

## Secret Scopes

| Scope | Access |
|-------|--------|
| **Repository** | Single repo |
| **Environment** | Specific deployment |
| **Organization** | All org repos |

> âš ï¸ **Security:** Secrets are masked in logs but still accessible by code!

slides.title: Creating Artifacts
slides.content:
# Creating and Using Artifacts ğŸ“¤

## GitHub Actions

### Upload Artifacts

```yaml
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Build
        run: npm run build
      
      - name: Upload build
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: build-output
          path: dist/
          retention-days: 5
```

### Download Artifacts

```yaml
jobs:
  deploy:
    needs: build
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Download build
        uses: actions/download-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: build-output
          path: ./dist
      
      - name: Deploy
        run: ./deploy.sh dist/
```

## GitLab CI

```yaml
build:
  stage: build
  script:
    - npm run build
  artifacts:
    paths:
      - dist/
    expire_in: 1 week

deploy:
  stage: deploy
  dependencies:
    - build
  script:
    - ./deploy.sh dist/
```

> ğŸ¯ **Note:** Artifacts are automatically passed in GitLab!

slides.title: Test Reports
slides.content:
# Test Report Artifacts ğŸ“Š

Display test results in CI interfaces.

## Publishing JUnit Reports

### GitHub Actions

```yaml
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Run tests
        run: npm test -- --reporter=junit --outputFile=results.xml
      
      - name: Publish test results
        uses: dorny/test-reporter@v1
        if: always()
        with:
          name: Jest Tests
          path: results.xml
          reporter: jest-junit
```

### GitLab CI

```yaml
test:
  stage: test
  script:
    - npm test -- --reporter=junit --outputFile=results.xml
  artifacts:
    when: always
    reports:
      junit: results.xml
```

## Report Types

| Report | Format | Use |
|--------|--------|-----|
| **JUnit** | XML | Test results |
| **Cobertura** | XML | Code coverage |
| **JaCoCo** | XML | Java coverage |
| **LCOV** | info | Line coverage |

## Benefits

- ğŸ“ˆ Visualize trends over time
- ğŸ” See failed test details
- ğŸ“Š Track coverage metrics
- ğŸš¦ Block PRs on test failures

slides.title: Caching
slides.content:
# CI Caching âš¡

Speed up builds by **reusing** files between runs.

## Why Cache?

```
Without Cache:                With Cache:
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€               â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Download deps: 2 min         Download deps: 10 sec (cached)
Build:         3 min         Build:         3 min
Total:         5 min         Total:         3 min 10 sec
                             Savings:       37%
```

## GitHub Actions Cache

```yaml
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Cache node modules
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: node_modules
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-node-${{ hashFiles('package-lock.json') }}
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-node-
      
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm ci
      
      - name: Build
        run: npm run build
```

## Cache Keys

| Key Component | Purpose |
|---------------|--------|
| `runner.os` | OS-specific cache |
| `hashFiles()` | Invalidate on file change |
| `restore-keys` | Fallback to older cache |

## Common Cache Targets

```
Node:    node_modules/
Python:  ~/.cache/pip
Ruby:    vendor/bundle
Java:    ~/.m2/repository
Go:      ~/go/pkg/mod
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Cache key should include lockfile hash!

slides.title: Notification Integration
slides.content:
# CI Notifications ğŸ””

Get notified about build results.

## Slack Integration

```yaml
jobs:
  notify:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    if: always()
    needs: [build, test]
    steps:
      - name: Notify Slack
        uses: slackapi/slack-github-action@v1
        with:
          payload: |
            {
              "text": "Build ${{ job.status }}",
              "blocks": [
                {
                  "type": "section",
                  "text": {
                    "type": "mrkdwn",
                    "text": "*Build:* ${{ github.workflow }}\n*Status:* ${{ job.status }}\n*Commit:* ${{ github.sha }}"
                  }
                }
              ]
            }
        env:
          SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL: ${{ secrets.SLACK_WEBHOOK }}
```

## Other Notification Channels

| Channel | Use Case |
|---------|----------|
| **Email** | Individual notifications |
| **Slack** | Team channels |
| **Teams** | Microsoft ecosystem |
| **Discord** | Open source projects |
| **PagerDuty** | On-call alerts |

## When to Notify

```yaml
# Only on failure
if: failure()

# Only on success
if: success()

# Always (success, failure, or cancelled)
if: always()

# Only on main branch
if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Only notify for failures to reduce noise!


## GitHub Actions Matrix

```yaml
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}
    strategy:
      matrix:
        os: [ubuntu-latest, macos-latest, windows-latest]
        node: [18, 20, 22]
        exclude:
          - os: windows-latest
            node: 18
        include:
          - os: ubuntu-latest
            node: 22
            experimental: true
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: ${{ matrix.node }}
      - run: npm test
```

## Matrix Options

| Option | Purpose |
|--------|--------|
| `include` | Add specific combinations |
| `exclude` | Remove specific combinations |
| `fail-fast` | Stop all on first failure |

slides.title: Reusable Workflows
slides.content:
# Reusable Workflows ğŸ”„

Share workflow logic across repositories.

## Creating a Reusable Workflow

```yaml
# .github/workflows/shared-build.yml
name: Shared Build

on:
  workflow_call:
    inputs:
      node-version:
        required: true
        type: string
    secrets:
      npm-token:
        required: true

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: ${{ inputs.node-version }}
      - run: npm ci
        env:
          NPM_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.npm-token }}
      - run: npm run build
```

## Using a Reusable Workflow

```yaml
# In consuming repository
name: CI
on: push

jobs:
  build:
    uses: org/shared-workflows/.github/workflows/shared-build.yml@main
    with:
      node-version: '20'
    secrets:
      npm-token: ${{ secrets.NPM_TOKEN }}
```

## Benefits

- ğŸ“¦ **DRY** - Don't repeat yourself
- ğŸ”§ **Maintainability** - Update once, apply everywhere
- âœ… **Consistency** - Standard processes
- ğŸ”’ **Security** - Centralized secret handling
